1;"The French Prime Minister has presented his plan to save 40 billion euros. Among his proposals is that patients should no longer have to bear the brunt of healthcare costs by being asked to expire in the shortest possible time. Report.
“We must no longer be a burden on our healthcare system
column2: ” reiterated François Bayrou
column3: who said he was counting on the responsibility of patients to “die quickly and well
column4: as part of a republican commitment and to avoid increasing the debt”. “You shouldn't put your long illness before the common good
column5: it's terribly selfish” also repeated the Prime Minister
column6: who wants to make patients aware of the costs borne by society for long

column1: To make savings
column2: several avenues are already being explored
column3: such as a tax on palliative care stays
column4: to encourage people to die at home and avoid unnecessarily overcrowding hospitals.";0

column1: Initially

column1: 3;"What is the expected effect of vaccination?
Vaccination involves presenting our body with a part (or the entirety) of a pathogen (virus
column2: bacterium) that has been previously inactivated or attenuated to render it harmless
column3: except in exceptional cases. The vaccinated person reacts against this theoretically inactive (fragment of) pathogen and develops an immune defense that will allow them to destroy the ""true"" pathogen during a subsequent potential infection. Thus
column4: an effective vaccine will
column5: in the event of an epidemic among unvaccinated individuals
column7: who will therefore not spread the disease and
column9: will not die from it. Furthermore
column10: a good vaccine offers protection that extends sufficiently over time so that immune memory does not need to be revitalized every season. A good vaccine offers protection for 10 years or more (diphtheria
column13: whooping cough) and in some cases for life (measles

column1: Observation of COVID-19 associated deaths for each age group
column2: before
column3: during
column4: and after vaccination

column1: The main risk factor for COVID-19 is age. Vaccination was therefore logically offered first to older people. Here
column2: we studied the evolution of the percentage of deaths over time
column3: according to age groups
column4: using data published by Santé Publique France. We conducted this study over three distinct periods:

column1: BEFORE vaccination
column2: from March 18
column4: to January 5

column1: DURING vaccination
column2: from January 6
column4: to December 31
column6: by which date we reached the vaccination plateau
column7: with more than 90% vaccination in the age groups concerned;

column1: AFTER vaccination
column2: from January 1
column4: to June 28

column1: Since older people were vaccinated first
column2: it was expected that their proportion of COVID-19 associated deaths would significantly decrease starting in spring 2021
column3: reaching a relative minimum in 2022
column4: as explained by the Ministry of Health
column5: vaccination against COVID-19 protects against severe cases and deaths

column1: However
column2: observation of the data reveals a completely different
column3: much less positive message
column4: visible in Figure 1. Figure 1: Evolution of the proportion of each age group in cumulative deaths from March 2020 to December 2021 (top graph)
column5: from January 2021 to the end of December 2021 (bottom left graph)
column6: and from early January 2022 to the end of June 2022 (bottom right graph). Blue bars represent the share (in %) of each age group in total deaths (left vertical axes)
column7: green bars represent the vaccination percentage for each age group at the end of the period (right vertical axes).

column1: We note that the percentage of deaths in the highest age groups does not vary significantly over these three periods.
For those 80 years and older: 62.4% before vaccination
column2: 59.9% during
column3: and 57.8% after;

column1: For those 70-79 years: 22% before vaccination
column2: 23.9% during
column3: and 22% after;

column1: For those 60-69 years: 10.6% before vaccination
column2: 12.3% during
column3: and 11.6% after.

column1: One might think that this stability reflects a uniform vaccine effectiveness across all age groups
column2: thus perfectly preserving the proportions of these different age groups. However
column3: the graphs of the number of deaths by age group (Figure 2) demonstrate that we remain within the same orders of magnitude of deaths (for example
column4: between 28
column6: 000 SARS-CoV-2 positive deaths over 12 months for those 80 and older)
column7: including for the first 6 months of 2022 during which the Omicron variant became widespread
column8: and for which COVID-19 mortality was quickly reported as very low [1]. Figure 2: Number of deaths in each age group
column9: from March 2020 to the end of December 2020 (top graph)
column10: from January 2021 to the end of December 2021 (bottom left graph)
column11: and from early January 2022 to the end of June 2022 (bottom right graph). Blue bars represent the number of deaths for each age group (left vertical axes)
column12: green bars represent the vaccination percentage for each age group at the end of the period (right vertical axes).

column1: These official public data strongly suggest that the vaccine has absolutely not controlled COVID-19 mortality in France. Furthermore
column2: recent data showing that the lethality of Omicron variants is ~3 times lower than that of previous variants [2] raises questions. We do not observe a decrease in overall mortality. The hypothesis that Omicron's greater contagiousness explains the still high number of deaths in France
column3: however
column4: goes against observations of deaths in sparsely vaccinated countries
column5: such as South Africa
column6: where the vaccination rate is 3 times lower than in France. Figure 3 shows that with a vaccination rate 3 times lower than France
column7: and the same dominance of the Omicron variant (100%)
column8: the number of deaths per million inhabitants in South Africa is much lower than in France. Figure 3: Comparison of France / South Africa data. Top left: same proportion of Omicron variant from February 2022 (100% in both countries); Vaccination rate ~3 times lower in South Africa than in France; Daily mortality significantly lower in South Africa than in France. The same period is represented in all three graphs.

column1: Conclusion
It is clear from these data that the proportion of deaths in age groups over 60 remains practically unchanged across the three periods studied: before
column2: during
column3: and after vaccination. This seems to indicate the inability of vaccines to limit COVID-19 mortality in the most vulnerable
column4: despite repeated messages from the Ministry of Health. Yet
column5: the disease itself is now different since the arrival of the less aggressive Omicron variants: it primarily affects the upper respiratory tract and no longer the lungs.

column1: Our political leaders seem to be gradually grasping these on-the-ground realities
column2: as they lifted the health pass this summer
column3: and thus the disguised vaccination mandate. Unfortunately
column4: suspended healthcare workers and firefighters have still not been reinstated
column5: even though both professions are short-staffed during these heatwave times... Common sense should nevertheless lead our leaders to reconsider the merits of these ""punishments"" which are not based on any scientific data.";0

column1: 4;"Introduction: Not a Rumor
column2: but a Solid Case File

column1: This page is based on comments I made last month
column2: in December 2021
column3: on the related page about the Covid crisis. After reviewing the entire case file at that time
column4: it seemed relevant to me to address the subject from its main angles
column5: prioritizing a genealogical approach because it more effectively allows us to understand what happened
column6: because I have experience in this field
column9: I am a distant cousin by marriage of the Trogneux family.

column1: How did this case impose itself on me? For some time
column2: I had heard talk
column3: to say the least astonishing
column4: about Brigitte Macron
column5: née Trogneux
column8: it was difficult for me to really grasp the allusions... In hindsight
column9: I realize that many people knew
column12: many knew before the revelation of the existence of a hidden daughter. On December 18
column14: I first heard in an article by Eric Verhaeghe that: ""the rumor is strangely alive
column15: claiming that Brigitte Macron is in fact a man
column16: or a trans person. This claim
column17: initially published in Faits & Documents in October 2021
column18: had not aroused much passion. One wonders why
column20: it is imposing itself as a scoop on social networks. Here again
column21: it smells like a campaign smear"" and ""In this chapter
column22: we will pour out the perfidious words uttered by Gérald Darmanin
column23: evoking Emmanuel Macron's husband and explaining that
column24: given the violence of the personal attacks
column25: the President was not yet sure whether to run"" (>>>18-second video>>>).

column1: I didn't really take notice
column2: as it was presented as a ""rumor."" A rumor among others... On the same December 18
column3: shortly after
column4: I found a well-argued article by Lionel Labosse which was based on the file from issue 501 of the journal ""Faits & Documents"" (here in pdf)
column5: published in early October 2021. The thesis was daring; was it supported? From that date
column7: I was able to directly read and analyze the essential part of the file that was the source of this ""rumor"" advancing the hypothesis that Brigitte Macron would be
column10: a male individual who would have taken on the social appearance of a woman. It is a long investigation by Xavier Poussard
column12: of whom there are too few currently. I found it well-structured
column13: posing relevant questions and making common-sense hypotheses. As a genealogy enthusiast
column14: I am used to conducting such investigations to find the parents of an ancestor
column15: weighing each hypothesis... The search for archival
column17: or biographical documents is well-conducted by the author. He notes their absence in large numbers
column18: which very quickly appears suspicious to him. And the same goes for certain inconsistencies that seem intentional

column1: After this initial study of the file and before undertaking a more in-depth analysis of its content
column2: I wanted to know the counterarguments. What was my surprise! While this revelation had been inflaming social media (in which I do not participate) for five days
column3: I found nothing serious in the official press to stop the rumor dead in its tracks. Yet it would have been very easy
column4: for example
column5: for Brigitte and Jean-Michel to appear together before a media outlet. Why had they not already done so? On the right
column10: this void is a sign of great embarrassment
column13: ""fake news"" is very quickly denied. The newspaper ""Libération
column14: mobilized on the front line to save the presidential couple's respectability
column18: by a few other newspapers. I read it carefully; it was completely fact-free and only resorted to ad personam attacks to discredit the investigator Natacha Rey
column19: the one who revealed the most difficult points to find in this case
column20: despite the fact that the Elysée services had strewn it with false leads. Despite the enormity of the attack
column21: the contrast between the seriousness of the incriminating file and the factual emptiness of ""Libération's"" journalistic pleas gave me the deep conviction that Xavier Poussard and Natacha Rey are telling the truth: Emmanuel Macron
column25: who had then become his fictional sister Brigitte
column26: born in 1953. The transformation would have taken place at the end of the 1970s. Before then
column27: Brigitte did not exist or was ""fabricated"" retrospectively
column29: 2022: I am leaving this view of the case that I had in January; we have since learned that it is not strictly accurate]. From being the father of his three children
column30: he would have become their mother. On this basis
column31: I proceeded as I do in genealogy: I adopted the hypothesis
column32: and then searched for the facts that would allow me to refine it.

column1: Should I give this (state) affair a large place on my page dedicated to Covid? I quickly answered yes for the reasons that will be presented later
column2: and I was therefore one of the first to report this information on a blog. The threat of a lawsuit wielded by the Elysée and reported by ""Libération"" seemed very artificial to me in the face of the reality of the facts. This page was started on January 14
column4: almost a month after my discovery of this Brigitte affair
column5: which I call the ""Brigittegate."" I am creating it because
column7: the media and politicians (including my MP
column8: as we will see) have decided
column10: to marginalize the affair and treat it with contempt as a rumor and a tissue of lies. It is therefore necessary to try to convince internet users of the validity of the questions and the hypothesis I have adopted. I am attempting this by dividing it into chapters that
column12: will allow the reader to navigate to the points that interest them. As Xavier Poussard writes
column13: ""The difficulty of this investigation is to untangle the true from the false."" It is not easy
column15: but it is possible that on some points
column17: this recognition of the true or the false may be questionable. Knowing this
column18: I will make corrections. I add that
column20: I am not bringing anything new except my family connection and a photo dating to 1953/1954; I am only repeating information that already exists elsewhere. I invite every reader to form their own opinion by confronting the hypothesis presented here with the legend told by the mainstream media
column21: based on the plausibility and coherence of the facts.";0

column1: 5;"Con: Temperatures were warmer than the present for much of the past 10
column2: 000 years. Image: Temperature reconstruction from present day to 11
column3: 300 years ago showing the warmer than today period known as the Holocene Climate Optimum. Key Takeaways:

column1: Climate activists and the mainstream media often claim temperatures have reached the “hottest in 125
column2: 000 years.”

column1: In reality
column2: temperatures were warmer than the present for much of the past 10
column3: 000 years
column4: including most of the time period that human civilization has existed.

column1: The warmer recent past has been long established by many data and sources
column2: including the very first United Nations climate assessment.

column1: Any recent claims of “hottest in 125
column2: 000 years” must show with specificity how and why these many long-established temperature histories
column3: which have long agreed with each other
column4: are wrong
column5: yet no compelling evidence has been presented. Short Summary:

column1: Present temperatures are unusually cool
column2: not warm. Scientific data has long shown that temperatures throughout most of the past 10
column3: 000 years were as warm or warmer than today. Recent modest warming has not changed that. The unusually cool present temperatures have been reported and demonstrated by multiple peer-reviewed studies
column4: data from the European Science Foundation
column5: and even the very first United Nations climate assessment. 1

column1: Even when we examine longer-term data
column2: present temperatures are unusually cool. We are presently in a warm period between ice age glaciations. Proxy data suggests that every one of the previous six interglacial warm periods were warmer than the present.5

column1: When climate activists claim temperatures are the hottest in 125
column2: 000 years
column3: they are ignoring and attacking long-established scientific data.

column1: In the image below
column2: scientists plot past temperatures as shown from ice core samples taken from the Greenland ice sheet. The warming of the past 150 years is minor
column3: and temperatures remain unusually cool compared with the past 10
column4: 000 years.7 Figure 1. Historic temperatures measured through Greenland ice cores. Since the last ice age glaciation ended 10
column5: 000 years ago
column6: temperatures have typically been much warmer than today. Source: Dahl-Jensen et al

column1: Also
column2: a 2013 study published in the peer-reviewed journal Science reconstructed temperatures from the present back to 11
column3: 300 years ago.  As seen in Figure 2
column4: the study confirms temperatures were much warmer during the Holocene Climatic Optimum than the present for most of the past 10
column5: 000 years.8
column6: 9 Figure 2: Temperature and carbon dioxide change during the Holocene. Black curve
column7: global temperature reconstruction by Marcott et al.
column9: CO2 levels as measured reported in Monnin et al.
column13: began increasing 8200 years ago even as temperatures

column1: The very first climate assessment report in 1990 from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) agreed. The chart below from the report shows that temperatures during most of the past 10
column2: 000 years were warmer than today.11 Figure 3: Temperature history according to the United Nations IPCC First Assessment Report. The top graph shows temperatures during the past 1 million years. The middle graph shows temperatures during the past 12
column3: 000 years. The bottom graph shows temperatures during the past 1
column4: 000 years. Present temperatures are at the far right. Source: IPCC First Assessment Report
column5: United Nations

column1: In summary
column2: the multitude of credible
column3: long-established scientific evidence conclusively shows that present temperatures are nowhere near the ‘hottest in 125
column4: 000 years.";0

column1: 10;"A gunman who killed four people when he stormed a skyscraper in the heart of New York on Monday evening left a note that appeared to blame the National Football League (NFL) for a brain injury
column2: the city's Mayor Eric Adams says.

column1: The attacker
column2: 27-year-old Shane Tamura of Las Vegas
column3: shot himself dead after opening fire in a building where the American football league has its headquarters
column4: but went to a different part of the building after taking the wrong lift.

column1: The gunman was carrying a note in which he blamed CTE
column2: a brain disease triggered by head trauma
column3: for his mental illness
column4: Adams said.

column1: Tamura played football as a teenager but did not play in the NFL
column2: ex-teammates have told US media.

column1: New York City police officer Didarul Islam
column2: 36 - who was working as a security guard at the building - was among those killed.

column1: Another of the victims was an employee of finance giant Blackstone
column2: who was named by her company as Wesley LePatner.

column1: Two male civilians were also killed. An NFL employee was also ""seriously injured"" in the attack
column2: the league's commissioner Roger Goodell wrote in a message to staff.

column1: Asked about a possible motive
column2: Adams told CBS: ""[He] did have a note on him. The note alluded to that he felt he had CTE
column3: a known brain injury for those who participate in contact sports.

column1: He appeared to have blamed the NFL for his injury.""
Tamura was a football player during his time at high school in California
column2: ex-teammates earlier told NBC News.

column1: The gunman appears to have driven across the US from Las Vegas to New York
column2: and used an assault-style rifle during the attack. After opening fire in the lobby
column3: Tamura is believed to have entered a lift to the 33rd floor of the skyscraper and continued to open fire.

column1: Mayor Adams said a preliminary investigation shows that the gunman mistakenly went to the office of Rudin Management
column2: which owns the building.

column1: Tamura later turned his gun on himself.

The incident brought parts of Midtown Manhattan and public transportation to a halt. A BBC journalist at the scene reported seeing scores of police vehicles and at least one person with a bloodied chest being taken away on a stretcher.
Bystanders reported hearing what sounded like gunshots and police told those in the area
column2: including the BBC journalist
column3: to shelter in nearby buildings.

column1: Police worked floor-by-floor to clear the building
column2: an effort that took hours.

column1: One woman
column2: Nekeisha Lewis
column3: said she was eating dinner with friends on the plaza when she heard gunfire. ""It felt like you were in a warzone almost
column4: she told NBC News.

column1: Ms Lewis said she saw an injured man run out of the building
column2: and described the incident as ""literally the most scary situation I've ever been in"".";1

column1: 11;"You sent us a video in which an alleged Mexican doctor advocates for the use of CDS (Chlorine Dioxide Solution) to treat COVID-19
column2: claiming it's a ""purer and more effective"" treatment than MMS (Miracle Mineral Solution)
column3: which contains sodium chlorite. He also provides a series of explanations on dosage for treating children. This information is false. There is no scientific evidence that chlorine dioxide or sodium chlorite are effective treatments for COVID-19
column4: and their consumption is dangerous.

column1: We are very interested in CDS
column2: as it is a purer and more effective treatment [than MMS] for treating COVID-19.""

column1: Organizations such as the U.S. FDA
column2: the WHO (through the Pan American Health Organization
column3: PAHO)
column4: and the Spanish Medicines Agency have issued statements highlighting the danger of chlorine dioxide (found in both MMS and CDS)
column5: unequivocally stating that consuming these compounds is equivalent to simply drinking ""bleach."" Indeed
column6: they are ""the active ingredients in some disinfectants"" and ""are not intended for human ingestion."" Furthermore
column7: these organizations emphasize that ""their ingestion or inhalation can cause severe side effects
column11: or diarrhea. The Spanish Agency of Medicines and Medical Devices (AEMPS) has also issued a warning
column12: stating that ""there is no scientific evidence supporting these supposed properties
column13: and these products have not undergone any form of scientific evaluation or authorization by the competent authorities to guarantee a positive benefit-risk ratio and thus ensure citizens' right to health protection."" In 2010
column14: it had already issued an informative note on the risk of their use
column15: ""given that products attributed with curative and preventive properties that do not have the mandatory authorizations are in violation of current regulations.""

column1: The presentation of CDS or MMS as an alternative treatment for COVID-19 is not new. False studies have even been published in what are known as predatory journals – those not listed in the official list of serious and globally recognized scientific publications – with the aim of legitimizing the supposed effectiveness of these alleged COVID-19 treatments. In this specific case
column2: this misinformation was disseminated by Manuel Aparicio
column3: director and owner of the Jurica Medical Center in Querétaro (Mexico)
column4: who had already been mentioned in other articles
column5: such as this one published by the Associated Press

column1: 12;"A new telomere repair mode unveiled
November 24
Scientific Findings

Telomeres are nucleoprotein structures that protect the ends of chromosomes and shorten with each cell division. This natural erosion of telomeres reflects successive cell divisions and is a marker of cellular aging. Using a yeast model
column2: Stéphane Coulon and Vincent Géli at the Cancer Research Center of Marseille reveal that eroded telomeres are subject to chromosomal rearrangements in quiescent cells. Remarkably
column3: these modifications reduce the ability of these cells to proliferate upon exiting quiescence. This work was published on November 22
column5: in the journal Nature Communications.

column1: Cell divisions cause telomere shortening which
column2: beyond a critical threshold
column3: limits the proliferative capacity of most cells in an organism. Embryonic stem cells and germ cells escape this anti-proliferative barrier because they express telomerase
column4: an enzyme capable of lengthening telomeres. In adults
column5: natural telomere attrition is primarily observed in somatic cells but also in stem cells where telomerase activity is reduced or absent. The natural attrition of telomeres can impair stem cell functions by limiting their ability to enter and exit quiescence to

column1: Telomere maintenance mechanisms are well-studied in dividing cells but remain poorly understood in quiescent (non-dividing) cells. It has been shown that DNA damage can lead to telomere shortening in quiescent cells
column2: particularly in neurons and muscle cells. The researchers investigated the fate of dysfunctional telomeres in quiescent cells. To study the mechanisms governing the maintenance of short telomeres in quiescent cells
column3: they used yeast cells whose quiescence can be metabolically induced. While telomeres in a wild-type strain are stable in quiescence
column4: they observed that eroded telomeres are strongly rearranged in the absence of telomerase. Unexpectedly for quiescent cells
column5: these rearrangements correspond to duplications of subtelomeric regions.

column1: These specific rearrangements
column2: never observed before
column3: depend on a DNA repair pathway called homologous recombination which primarily operates in dividing cells. The researchers discovered that the mechanism by which these rearrangements occur involves the transcription of non-coding RNA in these subtelomeric regions. Surprisingly
column4: these duplications in the subtelomeric regions decrease the cells' ability to initiate a new cell cycle.

column1: In summary
column2: this work highlights a new mode of telomere repair specific to post-mitotic yeast cells that limits the ability of these cells to exit quiescence.";1

column1: 13;"A young Lithuanian woman was struggling to conceive with her partner — a rare but shocking allergy was to blame for her infertility
column2: according to a new case report in a medical journal.

column1: For the 29-year-old patient
column2: four years of natural attempts and two rounds of IVF proved ineffective
column3: stumping her doctors.

column1: Since she’s asthmatic with a sensitivity to mold
column2: cat fur and dust
column3: the woman suspected that her allergies might be a contributing factor. Subsequent blood tests revealed that she had high levels of eosinophils
column4: a white blood cell that defends the body against allergens. In addition to her established allergies
column5: skin tests showed allergic sensitivity to mites
column7: insects and dogs. Tests also pinpointed high sensitivity to the protein Can f 5
column8: found in dog dander and urine
column9: which has been linked to potential sensitivities toward human semen.

column1: The woman shared with her allergist that she frequently experienced nasal congestion and sneezing after having unprotected sex with her partner. Using samples from her partner’s semen
column2: doctors confirmed that she has a semen allergy. A semen allergy
column3: also known as seminal plasma hypersensitivity (SPH)
column4: is a rare reaction to proteins found in male spermatic fluid
column5: according to the Cleveland Clinic. SPH is recognized as a Type 1 hypersensitivity
column7: exaggerated immune response to an allergen
column8: putting semen in the same category as peanuts and pet dander.

column1: For those afflicted
column2: reactions to exposure to ejaculate run the gamut from burning
column3: itching
column4: redness and swelling of the vulva or vagina to hives
column5: shortness of breath

column1: The primary treatment for SPH is condoms
column2: but in this case
column3: the woman was determined to conceive with her partner and eschewed the latex solution.

column1: SPH does not directly cause infertility
column2: though conception can be challenging.

column1: Treatments for would-be parents include antihistamine medication before intercourse
column2: anti-inflammatories after and/or desensitization therapy using diluted seminal plasma. In cases where the allergic reaction is severe
column3: some couples turn to using washed sperm free from seminal plasma in IVF treatments to divert the allergic trigger. Desensitization therapy was unavailable in Lithuania
column4: and the patient found antihistamines before sex to be “ineffective” at managing her reactions.

column1: During a follow-up visit three years later
column2: the woman disclosed that she was still unable to conceive and
column3: worse still
column4: her allergic symptoms had expanded to include eye irritation and a burning sensation in her vulva.

column1: Her case was detailed last year in the journal Frontiers in Medicine.
SPH was initially documented in 1967
column2: when a woman was hospitalized following a “violent allergic reaction” to sex.

column1: For the next three decades
column2: it was assumed that SPH affected fewer than 100 women worldwide.

column1: Yet
column2: a 1997 study led by allergist Jonathan Bernstein revealed that nearly 12% of reported postcoital symptoms could be classified as SPH.

column1: The condition is now believed to affect one in 40
column2: 000 people.";1

column1: 14;"One of Hollywood’s most recognizable and bankable stars wants to apologize if he fails to recognize you.
In a recent interview
column2: Brad Pitt claimed that he suffers from a rare neurological disorder known as prosopagnosia. Better known as “face blindness
column3: ” the condition limits your ability to recognize the faces of others
column4: sometimes even close friends and relatives.

column1: Though he has not been officially diagnosed
column2: Pitt says he has extreme difficulty recognizing other people’s faces. He adds that some have labeled him self-absorbed or conceited
column3: thinking he’s lying about having face blindness.

column1: Premier Health Now spoke with Fadi M. Tayim
column2: PhD
column3: a clinical neuropsychologist and Division Chief of the Brain Mapping Center at the Clinical Neuroscience Institute
column4: to learn more about prosopagnosia and how it is diagnosed.

column1: Hello
column2: Stranger

column1: “Because of its rarity
column2: prosopagnosia can be difficult to diagnose and there are even varying levels of severity
column3: ” says Dr. Tayim. “It is caused more commonly because of trauma such as a stroke or brain injury
column4: which causes damage to a fold of the brain associated with facial perception. It can also occur as a congenital defect that someone is born with.”

column1: According to the National Institutes of Health
column2: prosopagnosia is an extremely rare condition believed to occur in about two percent of the general population. Studies have shown that the average person is able to recognize and remember thousands of faces throughout their lifetime. But those who suffer from face blindness can struggle to make those same basic connections.

column1: Prosopagnosia specifically affects your visual recognition of other people. It’s not the result of memory loss
column2: such as the inability to remember a person’s name even though you may recognize their face.

column1: Dr. Tayim says
column2: “I would encourage anyone who thinks they might be suffering from face blindness to get in touch with their primary care physician
column3: who can then refer them to a neurologist or neuropsychologist for further testing.

column1: “There are a series of facial recognition tests and tasks that can be performed
column2: as well as imaging tests such as MRI that can be used to help identify any changes in the brain.”  ";1
